articles.headline: Insurance on Lehman Debt Is the Industry’s Next Test
articles.snippet: Sellers of insurance on bonds issued by Lehman Brothers are now likely to face demands that they pay out more than 91 cents on the dollar to buyers of those insurance contracts.
articles.abstract: Sellers of insurance on bonds issued by Lehman Brothers are now likely to face demands that they pay out more than 91 cents on the dollar to buyers of those insurance contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: First the house of Lehman fell. Now the insurance bill is coming due.

articles.headline: China May Let Peasants Sell Rights to Farmland
articles.snippet: The shift could draw hundreds of millions of farmers more firmly into China’s city-centered market economy.
articles.abstract: The shift could draw hundreds of millions of farmers more firmly into China’s city-centered market economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese leaders are expected to allow peasants to buy or sell land-use rights for the first time, a step that could draw hundreds of millions of farmers more firmly into the market economy, now centered around the cities.

articles.headline: One Thing You Can Control: Your Credit Score
articles.snippet: Tips for improving your credit standing since your credit score is something that you have a fair bit of control over.
articles.abstract: Tips for improving your credit standing since your credit score is something that you have a fair bit of control over.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly impossible to think about much other than retirement, college or other savings in recent days. The pain has been all too acute and, unfortunately, the damage is not contained. Lurking beyond the devastation in the markets are other problems, like the fact that consumers are having an increasingly hard time getting loans.

articles.headline: Alaska Inquiry Concludes Palin Abused Powers
articles.snippet: Gov. Sarah Palin abused the powers of her office by pressuring subordinates to fire her former brother-in-law, a state trooper, an investigation concluded.
articles.abstract: Gov. Sarah Palin abused the powers of her office by pressuring subordinates to fire her former brother-in-law, a state trooper, an investigation concluded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Sarah Palin abused the powers of her office by pressuring subordinates to try to get her former brother-in-law, a state trooper, fired, an investigation by the Alaska Legislature has concluded. The inquiry found, however, that she was within her right to dismiss her public safety commissioner, Walt Monegan, who was the trooper’s boss.

articles.headline: Economic Uncertainty Spreads
articles.snippet: Around the world, fears of recession have fed a stock market panic, as worries about toxic assets spread from the financial sector to the credit markets and now to the broader economy.
articles.abstract: Around the world, fears of recession have fed a stock market panic, as worries about toxic assets spread from the financial sector to the credit markets and now to the broader economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Korea, exporters are suddenly struggling.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Carter Dougherty

articles.headline: Swept Up by Insanity of Markets
articles.snippet: We find ourselves experiencing the same kind of financial panic that has dogged mankind at least since the Dutch tulip mania of the 1630s.
articles.abstract: We find ourselves experiencing the same kind of financial panic that has dogged mankind at least since the Dutch tulip mania of the 1630s.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I can calculate the motions of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people.”  Isaac Newton, 1721, after the South Sea bubble burst.

articles.headline: G.M. and Chrysler Explore Merger
articles.snippet: General Motors is in preliminary talks about a possible merger with Chrysler, which could remake the auto industry.
articles.abstract: General Motors is in preliminary talks about a possible merger with Chrysler, which could remake the auto industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors is in preliminary talks about a possible merger with Chrysler, a deal that could drastically remake the landscape of the auto industry by reducing the Big Three of Detroit automakers to the Big Two.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Rich Nations Pushing for Joint Financial Rescue
articles.snippet: The United States and six other nations agreed to a plan to rescue the financial industry, but fell short of offering concrete steps to backstop bank lending.
articles.abstract: The United States and six other nations agreed to a plan to rescue the financial industry, but fell short of offering concrete steps to backstop bank lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and six other nations that are among the world’s richest agreed on Friday to a coordinated plan to rescue the financial industry, but fell short of offering concrete steps to backstop bank lending on a day when fear tightened its grip on investors from Wall Street to Hong Kong.

articles.headline: As Stock Falls, Morgan Looks to Japanese Bank
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley was racing to secure its financial lifeline from a big Japanese bank as confidence in the embattled Wall Street bank continued to erode.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley was racing to secure its financial lifeline from a big Japanese bank as confidence in the embattled Wall Street bank continued to erode.
articles.lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley was racing on Friday to secure its financial lifeline from a big Japanese bank as confidence in the embattled Wall Street bank continued to erode.

articles.headline: North Korea Is Off Terror List After Deal With U.S.
articles.snippet: Saying North Korea had agreed to adhere to nuclear concessions, the U.S. took it off a list of terrorism sponsors.
articles.abstract: Saying North Korea had agreed to adhere to nuclear concessions, the U.S. took it off a list of terrorism sponsors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration announced Saturday that it had removed North Korea from a list of state sponsors of terrorism in a bid to salvage a fragile nuclear deal that seemed on the verge of collapse.

articles.headline: White House Overhauling Rescue Plan
articles.snippet: A new plan to inject capital into banks raises questions about whether officials squandered time selling an earlier bailout approach.
articles.abstract: A new plan to inject capital into banks raises questions about whether officials squandered time selling an earlier bailout approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As international leaders gathered here on Saturday to grapple with the global financial crisis, the Bush administration embarked on an overhaul of its own strategy for rescuing the foundering financial system.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Amid the Gloom, an E-Commerce War
articles.snippet: Seven years ago, eBay was an online juggernaut and Amazon.com its weaker rival. How times have changed.
articles.abstract: Seven years ago, eBay was an online juggernaut and Amazon.com its weaker rival. How times have changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the e-commerce giant eBay emerged from the last recession seven years ago with an aura of invincibility, its chief executive, Meg Whitman, boasted that “eBay is to some extent recession-proof.”

articles.headline: Regulators in Need of Rehab
articles.snippet: Regulators have completely squandered any trust that taxpayers may have had in them. Earning it back is going to take time and a commitment to transparency.
articles.abstract: Regulators have completely squandered any trust that taxpayers may have had in them. Earning it back is going to take time and a commitment to transparency.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCK market investors, even more than the average Jane, hate unpleasant surprises. Unfortunately, as last week showed, this bailout business is chock full of them.

articles.headline: Those With a Sense of History May Find It’s Time to Invest
articles.snippet: Some investors say that the sell-off has gone too far and that stocks could stage a powerful rally.
articles.abstract: Some investors say that the sell-off has gone too far and that stocks could stage a powerful rally.
articles.lead_paragraph: The four most dangerous words for investors are: This time is different.

articles.headline: Got $700 Billion? Sweat the Details
articles.snippet: The bailout bill is laden with all kinds of vague legislative guidelines and there are lots of details the next Treasury secretary will have to grapple with.
articles.abstract: The bailout bill is laden with all kinds of vague legislative guidelines and there are lots of details the next Treasury secretary will have to grapple with.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE House of Representatives was against the bailout bill before it was for it. But now it’s the law of the land, and the hard part begins: putting this $700 billion plan into effect under legislative guidelines that are, shall we say, vague. Never has that cliché “the devil is in the details” been more appropriate.

articles.headline: Schools Open, and First Test Is Iraqi Safety
articles.snippet: The start of school is a test of Iraq’s overall improvement: whether uprooted families are confident enough to return.
articles.abstract: The start of school is a test of Iraq’s overall improvement: whether uprooted families are confident enough to return.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  On the first day of school, 10-year-old Basma Osama looked uneasy standing in formation under an already stifling morning sun. She and dozens of schoolmates listened to a teacher’s pep talk  probably a necessary one, given the barren and garbage-strewn playground.

articles.headline: Concern in G.O.P. After Rough Week for McCain
articles.snippet: Republicans said that they were worried John McCain was heading for defeat without a clear message.
articles.abstract: Republicans said that they were worried John McCain was heading for defeat without a clear message.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a turbulent week that included disclosures about Gov. Sarah Palin and signs that Senator John McCain was struggling to strike the right tone for his campaign, Republican leaders said Saturday that they were worried Mr. McCain was heading for defeat unless he brought stability to his presidential candidacy and settled on a clear message to counter Senator Barack Obama.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: In Hard Times, Lawyers Advise Cautious Steps
articles.snippet: Two employment lawyers discuss some of the conflicts they expect to arise as financial companies disappear, change, merge and downsize.
articles.abstract: Two employment lawyers discuss some of the conflicts they expect to arise as financial companies disappear, change, merge and downsize.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS the turmoil on Wall Street continued, I sat down with two employment lawyers  Zachary Hummel, who represents employers, and Mark Risk, who represents employees  to discuss some of the conflicts they expect to arise as financial companies disappear, change, merge and downsize.

articles.headline: Morgan Agrees to Revise Terms of Mitsubishi Deal
articles.snippet: The Japanese bank demanded better terms after Morgan Stanley’s stock lost about 59 percent of its value.
articles.abstract: The Japanese bank demanded better terms after Morgan Stanley’s stock lost about 59 percent of its value.
articles.lead_paragraph: The embattled investment bank Morgan Stanley announced Monday morning that it had closed its deal to sell a 21 percent stake to a large Japanese bank, securing a $9 billion lifeline.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: L.A. Follows Its Own Script
articles.snippet: People who finance Hollywood continue to make large bets that people will still go to the movies.
articles.abstract: People who finance Hollywood continue to make large bets that people will still go to the movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood

articles.headline: Newspapers’ Web Revenue Is Stalling
articles.snippet: Newspapers, already facing a grim economic forecast, are digesting another piece of bad news.
articles.abstract: Newspapers, already facing a grim economic forecast, are digesting another piece of bad news.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newspapers, already facing a grim economic forecast, are digesting another piece of bad news: the growth in online advertising they saw as their salvation has slowed to a crawl.

articles.headline: Margin Calls Prompt Sales, and Drive Shares Even Lower
articles.snippet: Those who had bought stocks using borrowed money have been forced to sell millions to settle so-called margin loans with banks.
articles.abstract: Those who had bought stocks using borrowed money have been forced to sell millions to settle so-called margin loans with banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some big investors and corporate executives, Mr. Margin is calling.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: A Potential Merger Weighs on Detroit
articles.snippet: Merger talks between General Motors and Chrysler are a gut-punch to a city reeling from scandal and a downturn.
articles.abstract: Merger talks between General Motors and Chrysler are a gut-punch to a city reeling from scandal and a downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Motor City spent the weekend considering the once-unthinkable prospect that its traditional Big Three automakers might shrink to the Big Two.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Hindu Threat to Christians: Convert or Flee
articles.snippet: Christians in eastern Orissa State in India say they are being forced to leave their faith in exchange for safety.
articles.abstract: Christians in eastern Orissa State in India say they are being forced to leave their faith in exchange for safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOREPANGA, India — The family of Solomon Digal was summoned by neighbors to what serves as a public square in front of the village tea shop.

articles.headline: Bold Pledges From Leaders, but Investors Await Details
articles.snippet: Europe’s decision to guarantee lending between banks has thrown the spotlight back to the United States, where officials are said to be studying the feasibility of doing likewise.
articles.abstract: Europe’s decision to guarantee lending between banks has thrown the spotlight back to the United States, where officials are said to be studying the feasibility of doing likewise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After a whirl of emergency meetings, government leaders on both sides of the Atlantic made bold promises to rescue the global financial system, but were still racing to work out the details to calm battered stock markets before they opened on Monday morning.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: After Weekend Financial Huddle, No Sign That Lenders Will Thaw
articles.snippet: There is concern that new guarantees could cost American taxpayers far more money.
articles.abstract: There is concern that new guarantees could cost American taxpayers far more money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

articles.headline: U.S. Missteps Are Evident, but Europe Is Implicated
articles.snippet: Experts say lenders in Europe all too willingly embraced many of the riskiest practices of their American counterparts.
articles.abstract: Experts say lenders in Europe all too willingly embraced many of the riskiest practices of their American counterparts.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  A week ago, European leaders said they knew who was responsible for the global credit crisis.

articles.headline: Writing Memoir, McCain Found a Narrative for Life
articles.snippet: The story line of Senator John McCain’s 1999 memoir, “Faith of My Fathers,” reshaped his political identity.
articles.abstract: The story line of Senator John McCain’s 1999 memoir, “Faith of My Fathers,” reshaped his political identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For 25 years after his release from a North Vietnamese prison, Senator John McCain tried to build a reputation as more than a famous former captive. “I never want to be a professional P.O.W.,” he often told friends. He refused to let his campaigns use pictures from his incarceration, and he never mentioned his torture.

articles.headline: The Man Behind the Whispers About Obama
articles.snippet: Andy Martin, credited with starting a whisper campaign about Barack Obama, has been thrust into the spotlight.
articles.abstract: Andy Martin, credited with starting a whisper campaign about Barack Obama, has been thrust into the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most persistent falsehood about Senator Barack Obama’s background first hit in 2004 just two weeks after the Democratic convention speech that helped set him on the path to his presidential candidacy: “Obama is a Muslim who has concealed his religion.”

articles.headline: Stocks Soar 11 Percent on Aid to Banks
articles.snippet: Last week’s stock sell-off gave way to a big rally as countries around the world took steps to ease the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Last week’s stock sell-off gave way to a big rally as countries around the world took steps to ease the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Monday, for the first time this October, the Dow Jones industrial average ended the day higher than it began. Nine hundred and thirty-six points higher, to be exact, making for the biggest single-day percentage gain in 75 years.

articles.headline: Professor and Columnist Wins Economics Nobel
articles.snippet: Paul Krugman, a professor at Princeton and a columnist for The Times, won for his work on global trade patterns.
articles.abstract: Paul Krugman, a professor at Princeton and a columnist for The Times, won for his work on global trade patterns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul Krugman, a professor at Princeton and an Op-Ed page columnist for The New York Times, was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science on Monday.
